question: What advantage do radio telescopes have in cloudy or dusty conditions compared to optical telescopes?

content.source_1: Ground-based optical telescopes cannot observe through opaque cloud cover because clouds strongly scatter and absorb visible light; observers must wait for clear skies.
content.source_2: At centimeter-to-meter radio wavelengths, atmospheric clouds are largely transparent, so radio telescopes can collect signals in cloudy conditions and even during daylight.
content.source_3: Interstellar dust that blocks visible light is mostly transparent at radio wavelengths; radio observations can penetrate dusty star-forming regions that are hidden to optical telescopes.
content.source_4: Millimeter and submillimeter radio astronomy (tens to hundreds of GHz) is severely limited by atmospheric water vapor; even thin clouds can render observations unusable, so facilities like ALMA require extremely dry, cloud-free sites.
content.source_5: Clouds contain liquid water and ice that increase atmospheric opacity and emission at microwave, millimeter, and submillimeter frequencies (e.g., near strong water-vapor lines), raising system noise and often preventing observations under cloudy, humid conditions.
content.source_6: Adaptive optics can correct atmospheric turbulence for optical telescopes but cannot overcome cloud opacity; visible light remains blocked by clouds regardless of such corrections.

answer: ability to see through clouds and dust
